coredata.dc:title: Non-and near-resonant (vv) energy transfer between the isotopes of N2 and of CO in liquid Ar and in the gas phase at 85 k
coredata.dc:creator: Williams, H.T.
Gwynne, S.V.
Simpson, C.J.S.M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Rate constants for vibrational energy transfer have been measured in the system N2(v= 1) +CO(v=0) as a function of energy mismatch by using isotopic derivatives of N2 and of CO. These rate constants have been determined both in the gas phase and in liquid argon solution at 85 K. For non-resonant processes we find k L=k G for the nearest to resonant system we find k L <k G. This result is considered to arise because long range forces important in near-resonant energy transfer operate to a lesser extent in the liquid phase.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 136, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 July 1987 NON- AND NEAR-RESONANT (W) ENERGY TRANSFER BETWEEN THE ISOTOPES OF N, AND OF CO IN LIQUID Ar AND IN THE GAS PHASE AT 85 K H.T. WILLIAMS, S.V. GWYNNE and C.J.S.M. SIMPSON Physical Chemistry Laboratory, South Parks Road, Oxford 0X1 3QZ, UK Received 27 March 1987 Rate constants for vibrational energy transfer have been measured in the system N3(1'= 1) +CO(u=0) as a function of energy mismatch by using isotopic derivatives of N2 and of CO. These rate constants have been determined both in the gas phase and in liquid argon solution at 85 K. For non-resonant processes we find k^=ka', for the nearest to resonant system we find ki,<ka- This result is considered to arise because long range forces important in near-resonant energy transfer operate to a lesser extent in the liquid phase. 1. Introduction Recently we have published rate constants for non- resonant [1,2] and for near-resonant (VV) transfer processes [3] measured in liquid Ar solution at 1 atm pressure at 85 K and in the gas phase at the same temperature. Under these conditions we have found that for the nine systems which we have studied involving non- resonant (VV) transfer the rate constant in the liq- uid, ^L> is equal to that in the gas, ky, within a mean experimental error of 7%, and the more accurately we have been able to determine the ratios of k^Jko the closer they are to unity. We noted [2] that in all of these systems the values of T* given by kTle, where e is the intennolecular well depth, are all less than one. We have suggested that under these con- ditions near the gas-liquid coexistence boundary, the same intennolecular potential controls the value of the pair distribution functions, g^ and go, in the region of the potential responsible for energy trans- fer, giving rise to the same values ofg in each phase and the observed equality of rate constants. In all of the cases of near-resonant (W) transfer between the isotopic derivatives of CO and substi- tuted methane molecules which we have investigated we have found that the values ofk^ are less than those of ka at the same temperature [ 3 ]. Unfortunately, though the experimental evidence that <Ci, is less than kc for these systems is unambiguous, the interpre- tation of the results is difficult because it is uncertain exactly what energy mismatches are involved and which mechanisms of energy transfer predominate. For these reasons we have investigated the energy exchange between the isotopes of N2 and the iso- topes of CO, as, using this system, it is possible to change from non-resonant to near-resonant (VV) transfer using the same interaction potential with no ambiguity in the energy mismatch. 2. Experimental The apparatus and experimental techniques used by us have been described in our recent papers [ 1 -3 ]. The Ar, N2 and ^C^O were B.O.C. Research Grade, with specifications as given in ref. [2]. The cylinders containing '"N2 and ^C^O were cooled in solid CO; for several hours before use, while the Ar sample was further purified by passage through a solid COz/acetone cooled molecular sieve trap. The ^N2 and ^C^O were supplied by Amersham Interna- tional with the following purity levels. "N2: (99 at%) 99.8% N2, 0.04% 02, 0.03% Ar, 0.12% H20; WO: (99.7 at% "C, 98.6 at% '"O) 97.8% "C^O, 1.7% ^C^O^, 0.4% N2,0.1% '^ 0 009-2614/87/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 95 Volume 136, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 July 1987 The bulbs containing ^N2 and ^C^O were cooled in liquid N3 in order to freeze out HzO and COf This procedure was particularly important with the ^N2 as 40 ppm ofCC>2 in the ^N2 would make a signif- icant contribution to the rate and this would be very hard to detect by mass spectrometry. The most dif- ficult gas to use was "C^O. As noted in ref. [2], not only did this contain a significant impurity of air, but it also contained 7.5% ^C^O. Energy pumped into ^C^O is equilibrated rapidly into ^C^O on the time scale of these experiments. The ^C^O then contains an appreciable fraction of the pumping energy and allowance has to be made for its contri- bution to the observed rate of fluorescence decay. For this reason the rate constants for (VV) exchange between '"N2 and ^C^O are known less accurately than for the processes involving ^C^O, or "C^O. All gas mixtures were cooled with solid C02 in order to remove any residual water vapour. 3. Results Rate constants measured in the gas phase are pre- sented in table 1 in the exothermic direction. The results are shown in fig. 1. Our more accurate data for the relaxation of ^N2(1^=!) by ^C^O agree Table 1 Rate constants for the vibrational relaxation of ^N2(2'= 1) by '^"O and for "'N2(1^= 1) by 'WO in the gas phase. Upper curve, feVi^i.; -i:c"'o, ka 0; fci. Lower curve, kf^ -ncnoi ky 0; ki_ . For error bars see table 1. within experimental error with those of Alien and Simpson [4]. Rate constants in liquid Ar at 85 K are presented in table 2 for the system "N2(1^= 1) + ^C^O. Data for the other systems have been presented in our pre- vious papers [1,2]. The rate constants in liquid Ar at 85 K. are also shown in fig. 1. The liquid and gas phase data are compared at 85 K in table 3. Re&dA(B}=Axl011. b> Ratios of rate constants are calculated at the 95.5% confidence interval using the procedures ofCvetanovic et al. [ 5 ]. c) Gas phase data taken from ref. [ 4 ]. Unfortunately we were not able to obtain another sample of' '*N' 'N in order to measure fci.. "'Ref.tl]. "Refs.[4,6]. Ref.[2]. These data are shown as a plot of log k against A , the energy mismatch, at 85 K for both the gas and liquid phase data in fig. 2. 4. Discussion The results which we have obtained have shown that for non-resonant (VV) transfer between N3 and CO in liquid Ar at 85 K and 1 atm pressure, the rate constant in the liquid phase is the same as in the gas phase at this temperature, provided that the energy mismatch is greater than 187 cm"'. This finding supports our previous investigations of non-resonant (VV) transfer in liquid Ar under these conditions for other systems [ 1,2]. The calculations which we have made for energy transfer in the gas phase for N; (v= 1) deactivated by CO have shown that for the non-resonant processes the cross sections for transfer are governed largely by the steepness of the interaction potential at the clas- sical turning point for the trajectory concerned [7]. 240 260 AE/cm-1 Fig. 2. Plot oflog(rate constant) against energy mismatch for the vibrational relaxation of the isotopes of N2(1;= 1) by the isotopes of CO at 85 K. 0 ka, *:L. For error bars see table 3. 97 Volume 136, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 July 1987 The calculated rate constants agree with the exper- imental values within a factor of 2 for AE> 187 cm"'. For the process '^(i^O+^C^O, which is closest to resonance, the results calculated using a Morse potential underestimate the rate constant. The difference increases with decreasing temperature and is a factor of 3 at 85 K. We consider that this is due to the neglect of long range coupling forces due to the interaction between the quadrupole moment of N3 and the transition dipole moment of the CO in the potential used. Indeed for an energy mismatch of only 108 cm~1 energy transfer due to these long range forces would be expected to be important [8]. From fig. 2 it is apparent that there is a linear dependence between log k and AE for the non-res- onant processes in both the gas and the liquid phase. This relationship holds for all of the results in the liquid phase, but in the gas phase the rate constants for the processes closest to resonance are larger than would be expected from the linear dependence between \ogk and A '. For the case of "N2(1^= 1) + "C^O the rate constant in the gas phase is a factor of 1.5 greater than that in the liquid. This is clearly outside the experimental uncertainties of 3% in the values of fci, and ko for this process. The statistical theory proposed by Chesnoy [9] using the Andersen, Weeks and Chandler potential predicts that fei. < ko for processes taking place at val- ues of.R* greater than a/we and therefore offers an explanation as to why k^<ko for ^N2 deactivated by ^C^O. However this is not a satisfactory expla- nation since the same theory predicts that k^ > ko for the non-resonant (VV) processes whereas the exper- imental finding is that k^=ko. We suggest that the difference between the values of ^L and ko for the near-resonant (VV) processes arises because long range forces are more important in causing energy transfer in the gas phase than in liquid Ar near the coexistence region. This expla- nation can also account for our finding that for near- resonant energy transfer between CO isotopes and CD4, CD3H and CF4 ^ is about 5^3 [3]. We shall investigate other cases of near-resonant energy transfer for which there is no possible ambi- guity about the energy mismatch in order to estab- lish whether long range forces are much less important in causing energy transfer between sub- stances dissolved in cryogenic liquids than in the gas phase at the same temperature. Our results obtained thus far suggest that this is a general phenomenon. Acknowledgement We wish to thank the SERC for a grant to support this research. We are indebted to Mr. Clutterbuck for work on the design of the liquids cell and Mr. Richards for its manufacture. References [ 1 ] M.R. Buckingham, H.T. Williams, R.S. Pennington, C.J.S.M. Simpsonand M.M. Maricq, Chem. Phys. 98 (1985) 179. [2] H.T. Williams, M.H. Purvis and C.J.S.M. Simpson, Chem. Phys., to be published. [3] H.T. Williams, M.H. Purvis, M.R. Buckingham and C.J.S.M. Simpson, Chem. Phys., to be published. [4] D.C. Alien and C.J.S.M. Simpson, Chem. Phys. 45 (1980) 203. [ 5 ] R.J. Cvetanovic, D.L. Singleton and G.E. Paraskevopoulos, J. Phys. Chem. 8 3(1979) 50. [6] E.T. Chandler, E.A. Gregory, R.M. Siddles and C.J.S.M. Simpson, Chem. Phys. Letters 78 (1981) 236. [7] M.M. Maricq, E.A. Gregory and C.J.S.M. Simpson, Chem. Phys.95 (1985) 43. [8] J.T. Yardley, Introduction to molecular energy transfer (Academic Press, New York, 1980). [9] J. Chesnoy, Chem. Phys. 83 (1984) 283. 98 rocesses the cross sections for transfer are governed largely by the steepness of the interaction potential at the clas- sical turning point for the trajectory concerned [7]. 240 260 AE/cm-1 Fig. 2. Plot oflog(rate constant) against energy mismatch for the vibrational relaxation of the isotopes of N2(1;= 1) by the isotopes of CO at 85 K. 0 ka, *:L. For error bars see table 3. 97 Volume 136, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 July 1987 The calculated rate constants agree with the exper- imental values within a factor of 2 for AE> 187 cm"'. For the process '^(i^O+^C^O, which is closest to resonance, the results calculated using a Morse potential underestimate the rate constant. The difference increases with decreasing temperature and is a factor of 3 at 85 K. We consider that this is due to the neglect of long range coupling forces due to the interaction between the quadrupole moment of N3 and the transition dipole moment of the CO in the potential used. Indeed for an energy mismatch of only 108 cm~1 energy transfer due to these long range forces would be expected to be important [8]. From fig. 2 it is apparent that there is a linear dependence between log k and AE for the non-res- onant processes in both the gas and the liquid phase. This relationship holds for all of the results in the liquid phase, but in the gas phase the rate constants for the processes closest to resonance are larger than would be expected from the linear dependence between \ogk and A '. For the case of "N2(1^= 1) + "C^O the rate constant in the gas phase is a factor of 1.5 greater than that in the liquid. This is clearly outside the experimental uncertainties of 3% in the values of fci, and ko for this process. The statistical theory proposed by Chesnoy [9] using the Andersen, Weeks and Chandler potential predicts that fei. < ko for processes taking place at val- ues of.R* greater than a/we and therefore offers an explanation as to why k^<ko for ^N2 deactivated by ^C^O. However this is not a satisfactory expla- nation since the same theory predicts that k^ > ko for the non-resonant (VV) processes whereas the exper- imental finding is that k^=ko. We suggest that the difference between the values of ^L and ko for the near-resonant (VV) processes arises because long range forces are more important in causing energy transfer in the gas phase than in liquid Ar near the coexistence region. This expla- nation can also account for our finding that for near- resonant energy transfer between CO isotopes and CD4, CD3H and CF4 ^ is about 5^3 [3]. We shall investigate other cases of near-resonant energy transfer for which there is no possible ambi- guity about the energy mismatch in order to estab- lish whether long range forces are much less important in causing energy transfer between sub- stances dissolved in cryogenic liquids than in the gas phase at the same temperature. Our results obtained thus far suggest that this is a general phenomenon. Acknowledgement We wish to thank the SERC for a grant to support this research. We are indebted to Mr. Clutterbuck for work on the design of the liquids cell and Mr. Richards for its manufacture. References [ 1 ] M.R. Buckingham, H.T. Williams, R.S. Pennington, C.J.S.M. head.ce:title: Non-and near-resonant (vv) energy transfer between the isotopes of N2 and of CO in liquid Ar and in the gas phase at 85 k

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Physical Chemistry Laboratory, South Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3QZ, UK

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Rate constants for vibrational energy transfer have been measured in the system N2(v= 1) +CO(v=0) as a function of energy mismatch by using isotopic derivatives of N2 and of CO. These rate constants have been determined both in the gas phase and in liquid argon solution at 85 K. For non-resonant processes we find k L=k G for the nearest to resonant system we find k L <k G. This result is considered to arise because long range forces important in near-resonant energy transfer operate to a lesser extent in the liquid phase.
